sec.p: 1 . Body shape
0: Cylindrical.
1 : Expanded posterior.
0: Mucous and sediment tube.
1 : Lined, blind, burrow in calcium carbonate.

Most sabellids construct a tube from mucus and sediment. Some such as Amphiglena terebro Rouse 1993 , and some Perkinsiana Knight-Jones, 1983 and Pseudopotamilla Bush, 1905 , (see
Chughtai & Knight-Jones 1988 ) can seemingly burrow into calcareous substrates. Most Amphiglena form normal sabellid tubes and the outgroup condition is scored as such based on the derived placement of A. terebro in the genus found by
Fitzhugh & Rouse ( 1999 )
. The possibility that the burrowing by A. terebro is homologous with Caobangia and Terebrasabella does deserve further investigation.
3 . Segmentation
0: Obvious segments along body.
1 : Posterior segmentation not obvious.
In most sabellids the segments are clearly obvious but the posterior sac-like bodies of Caobangia and Terebrasabella show few external signs of segments beyond their chaetae. 4 . Faecal groove
0: Completely ciliated.
1 : Two distinct bands.

The restriction of the cilia in the faecal groove to two well-developed bands along the lateral faecal groove margins has only been found in Caobangia and Terebrasabella (
Fitzhugh & Rouse 1999 )
. 5 . Radioles
0: Three or more pairs.
1 : Two pairs.

Apart from Terebrasabella , two pairs of radioles are known in Manayunkia Leidy, 1859 , which is part of Fabriciinae , and so would appear to represent a convergence. Caobangia species have three pairs of radioles (
Jones 1974 ), while Amphiglena species have four or more pairs of radioles (
Rouse & Gambi1997 ). 6 . Thoracic uncini chaetigers 2–6
0: Teeth over main fang homodont.
1 : Lateral teeth larger than others – heterodont.
2 : No uncini.

In Amphiglena and in T. fitzhughi sp. nov. , the teeth over the main fang of the uncini are all of similar size, a condition found in many Sabellidae . In T. heterouncinata and T. hutchingsae sp. nov. , the two lateral-most teeth are much larger than the other teeth. Unique among sabellids, Caobangia species lack uncini on chaetigers 2–6 , though they do have large “hooks” on chaetiger one, though the homologies of this structure have yet to be determined.
7 . Thoracic uncini chaetigers 7–8
0: Same as in chaetigers 2–6 .
1 : Rasp-shaped avicular uncini.
2 : No uncini.

Fitzhugh ( 1989 )
discussed uncinal types in sabellids and preferred not use the terms acicular and avicular. The former he defined as having long handles that are gently curved, proximal extensions of the distal dentate end. He defined avicular uncini as characteristically Z-shaped or swan-shaped with the handle sharply bent below the main fang with the proximal part of the handle oriented about 90 ° relative to the distal part. However, the terms cover a wide variety of forms and so for cladistic analysis he broke up the features of uncini into several characters based on dentition, breast development and handle length. The terms acicular and avicular have been used throughout this paper, but with clear definitions. Terebrasabella , Brandtika Jones, 1974 and Potaspina Hartman, 1969 are the only sabellid genera to show two dramatically different sets of neuropodial uncini. In Potaspina the anterior thoracic chaetigers have avicular uncini in chaetigers 2–5 and the acicular uncini in most remaining thoracic chaetigers (
Fitzhugh & Rouse 1999 ;
Hartman 1969 ). In Terebrasabella there are acicular uncini in chaetigers 2–6 and chaetigers 7 and 8 have avicular uncini with rasp-shaped dentition and medium handles. Brandtika shows a difference between the acicular uncini of chaetigers 2–5 compared to the presence of ‘pilose hooks’ in chaetigers 6 and 8 (
Jones 1974 ), but the difference is not dramatic and currently this genus would appear to be best placed in Fabriciinae . In other sabellids, such as Amphiglena , where thoracic uncini are present they are essentially the same in each chaetiger along the thorax. Caobangia is unique in lacking thoracic uncini in chaetigers 2–8 .
8 . Companion chaetae
0: Present chaetigers 2–8 .
1 : Absent.
2 : Present chaetigers 2–6 .

Companion chaetae are found in front of the thoracic uncini in a number of Sabellinae and are usually found in chaetigers 2–8 . However, in Calcisabella , Potaspina and Terebrasabella they are found in a more limited number of thoracic chaetigers. In Calcisabella the companion chaetae are found from chaetigers 4–8 (
Perkins 1991 ). In Potaspina they are present in chaetigers 2–4 only (
Hartman 1969 ) and in all Terebrasabella species they are present in chaetigers 2–6 . In Caobangia , as in many other sabellids, companion chaetae are absent.
9 . Abdominal uncini
0: Avicular with short to medium handles, large breast.
1 : Long-handled with small breast (= acicular).
2 : Rasp-shaped, no handles.

Amphiglena species have classic avicular abdominal uncini with handles that vary from short to medium in length (
Rouse & Gambi1997 ). Caobangia has rasp-shaped uncini (though with a main fang, unlike Fabriciinae ) with no handles (
Fitzhugh 1989 ) and hence are neither acicular or avicular. Terebrasabella and Jasminiera species are the only sabellids that possess acicular abdominal uncini. 10 . Teeth of abdominal uncini
0: Evenly-sized over main tooth (homodont)
1 : Various sizes; approaching “palmate” condition

In Amphiglena , Caobangia and in T. fitzhughi sp. nov. , the teeth over the main fang of the abdominal uncini are all of similar size, a condition found in many Sabellidae . In T. heterouncinata and T. hutchingsae sp. nov. , the teeth vary in size and form a distinct arch over the main fang. 11 . Adult abdominal segment number
0: Numerous and variable
1 : Always three

Three abdominal segments is a condition found in many Fabriciinae but a variable number of abdominal segments in normally found among Sabellinae and no derived sabellins apart from Terebrasabella show such a limited number of abdominal segments.

sec.title: Results
sec.p:
A single shortest tree was found with a length of 15 steps and a consistency index of 1 . This tree is shown in
. The monophyly of Caobangia plus Terebrasabella was supported by several apomorphies: 1 . A ‘teardrop’ body shape with expanded posterior end; 2 . Living in a blind burrow in calcium carbonate; 3 . Posterior segmentation not obvious; and 4 . A faecal groove with two distinct ciliated bands. There were two unequivocal apomorphies supporting the monophyly of Terebrasabella : 5 . Two pairs of radioles; and 11 . Three abdominal segments. Characters 7, 8 and 9 were based on uncini or companion chaetae and were all multistate with different states for Caobangia and Terebrasabella . There are three most parsimonious character optimisations for each of these characters and thus it is not possible to decide whether the states for either Terebrasabella or Caobangia for each of these characters are apomorphic for the respective genera. However, in two of the possible three transformations for each of characters 7–9 the states are apomorphies for the respective genera and so they are marked as supporting these nodes (though marked with *). For Terebrasabella this suggests that there may be three further apomorphies: 7 . Rasp-shaped avicular uncini in chaetigers 7–8 ; 8 . Companion chaetae on chaetigers 2–6 only; and 9 . Acicular uncini in abdominal chaetigers. Within Terebrasabella ,
it would appear that T. heterouncinata and T. hutchingsae sp. nov. , are sister groups based on the expanded lateral teeth in thoracic uncini ( 6 ) and abdominal uncini ( 10 ).
Ecology and Life history of Terebrasabella spp.

The other known species Terebrasabella , T. heterouncinata lives in gastropod shells, but the mechanism of inserting itself into the shell is thought to initially be a passive mechanism whereby the mollusc secretes nacreous material over the top of newly-settled juveniles. It is suggested by
Fitzhugh & Rouse ( 1999 )
that because there is "some degree of burrow enlargement", there may be another method used in burrow formation, such as by chemical mediation. Terebrasabella fitzhughi sp. nov. , was extracted from burrows into a clump of spirorbin tubes, and it appears that in this case the species may be capable of 'active' burrowing. It is unfortunate that we did not have fresh specimens of T. hutchingsae sp. nov. , to examine. By the time of examination, 14 years after their collection from samples of dead coral "reef rock", any knowledge of how they were living in the substrate was lost (i.e. if they were living inside the coral rock itself or associated with molluscs collected in the same samples). Fresh material was sought from the Outer Barrier Reef in 1995 , but no specimens were found. However it seems valid to assume that it has a similar habitus as the other two species, i.e. it burrows into a CaCO 3 substratum.

Like T. heterouncinata , both T. fitzhughi sp. nov. , and T. hutchingsae sp. nov. , are hermaphroditic species, shown by the presence of both spermatids and oocytes inside specimens (including the holotype of T. hutchingsae sp. nov. ). The presence of juvenile/larval forms lying alongside adult worms inside their mucous sheaths, indicate that both species also brood direct-developing young. Also, branchial crowns were not observed on developing juveniles inside the mucous sheath, leading to a similar conclusion as that made for T. heterouncinata (
Fitzhugh & Rouse, 1999 )
, i.e. that branchial crowns do not develop on juveniles until final settlement has occurred.

Fitzhugh & Rouse ( 1999 )
stated that, for T. heterouncinata , avicular uncini in the thorax are gradually replaced during juvenile-to-adult development (dorsal to ventral) by acicular uncini. They also found that “animals < 0.7 mm in length only produce avicular uncini” (
Fitzhugh & Rouse ( 1999 : p. 368 )
. In contrast, the juvenile T. hutchingsae sp. nov. , inside mucous sheath of adult holotype (both approximately 0.4 mm in length) already possess acicular uncini, all of which are the “palmate” uncinus type . We feel it reasonable to suggest that the smaller “palmate” uncini lying in the neurochaetal position of chaetigers 3–5 of these juveniles must, as growth occurs, eventually be replaced by the other adult thoracic crested acicular and avicular uncini. Similarly for T. fitzhughi sp. nov. , juveniles of 8–11 chaetigers in length possessed few avicular uncini, or none at all at an even smaller size (~ 0.3 mm in length). Chaetal replacement of avicular with acicular uncini does not seem to be occurring in these two species.

sec.title: Acknowledgements
sec.p: We would like to thank Drs Penny Berents (formerly Weate) and Pat Hutchings (AM) for collecting the material from Lizard Island in 1977 and Paddy Patterson, Brett Dicks and Alastair Simpson for assisting with the Tasmania field trip. Geoff Avern and Sue Lindsey (AM) assisted with SEM, Carl Bento (AM) scanned the original SEM negatives, and Kate Attwood (AM) kindly provided information about the method of extraction of Lizard Island specimens, as well help with scanning the illustrations. And also thanks to Anne Hoggett and Lyle Vail of Lizard Island Research Station for their excellent hospitality. Thanks to Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority for permitting further exploratory collection in 1995 , which unfortunately yielded no other specimens.
Our gratitude also goes to Dr Maria Capa and another anonymous reviewer for advice and comments on the draft manuscript.
